title.narrative: Cordaid / CRS Dutch Joint Response Iraq 3 (IRQJR3)

description.narrative: Ninewa Governorate: First line WASH response At least 1500 Individuals (newly IDPs, remanies and returnees) get access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use in the villages of Qaritat, Abzagh, Hamza, Tel Hamid, Wardek, Astih. Second line WASH response At least 4200 Individuals (newly IDPs, remanies and returnees) get access to sustainable sufficient and safe water for domestic and communal use in the villages of Qaritat, Abzagh, Hamza, Tel Hamid, Wardek, Astih. Kirkuk Governorate: Second line WASH response 1,800 IDPs get access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use and access to dignified, safe, clean and functional sanitation (facilities).

The project will address the needs of the most in need people in Iraq in line with the main humanitarian assessments for Iraq. Newly displaced populations for Mosul and Hawija, residents of and returnees to newly ISIL liberated areas will be the main target group of this proposed intervention in Ninewa and Kirkul governorate . In both first and second line response , the priority and special attention will be given to the most vulnerable groups. The vulnerability criteria are mainstreamed in our programming by participatory bottom up approach and by integrating activities directly targeting the most vulnerable groups, women and children in particular. The host community will also be targeted in this intervention. In Ninewa activities they are part of the remains and returnees and in Kirkuk there will be around 10% of the total target group. Most in need host families will be selected following the described vulnerability criteria. Gender is mainstreamed throughout the programme. At the onset of the programme women and girls will be interviewed and specific data about women/ girls will be collected.

he proposed intervention focuses on WASH, one of the sectors with the biggest needs in Iraq and in line with all humanitarian information sources for the country. Currently more than 8.3 million people need WASH support whilst there is a financial gap of US$78 million already for the Mosul response only. The implementation areas of the project (Ninewa and Kirkuk), are both also highly prioritized in because of the current military operations in Mosul and Hawija (Tigris corridor). The newly ISIL liberated area of Al Hamdaniyah east of Mosul in Ninewa governorate, is one of the most affected areas as well as one of the most densely populated areas. Thousands of affected people in the area have no access to clean and safe water due to three main factors: 1. WASH infrastructure in most of the villages has been damaged; 2. Treatment plants that supply clean water from the Khabur river have been destroyed causing a lack of safe water; 3. Insufficient emergency WASH supplies and/or systems to attend the high demands in the area.

participating-org.narrative: Government of the Netherlands - Ministry of Foreign Affairs

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

provider-org.narrative: Government of the Netherlands - Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Government of the Netherlands - Ministry of Foreign Affairs

title.narrative: WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly from humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners.
